utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Alright, just a few more feet, and…. here we are gentlemen, the Gates of Elzebub.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good lord!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oooh.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Don’t panic, this is what the last 97 hours have been about.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Stay frosty, there’s a horde of armed goblins on the other side of that gate guarding the Sword of Azeroth.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Warriors, unsheathe your weapons, magic wielders raise your wands.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Lock and load.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Raj, blow up the gates.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Blowing the gates. Control, shift, B! Oh, my God, so many goblins!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Don’t just stand there, slash and move, slash and move.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Stay in formation.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Leonard, you’ve got one on your tail.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s alright, my tail’s prehensile, I’ll swat him off.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’ve got him Leonard. Tonight I spice my meat with goblin blood!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Raj, no, it’s a trap, they’re flanking us!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oooh, he’s got me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, he’s got Raj, use your sleath spell. Sheldon! Sheldon!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ve got the Sword of Azeroth!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Forget the sword, Sheldon, help Raj.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There is no more Sheldon, I am the Swordmaster!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Leonard look out!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Dammit man, we’re dying here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Goodbye, peasants.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: The bastard teleported.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: He’s selling the Sword of Azeroth on ebay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You betrayed us for money, who are you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m a rogue knight elf, don’t you people read character descriptions? Wait, wait, wait, somebody just clicked “buy it now.”

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I am the Swordmaster!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wooh, I’m all sweaty, anybody want to log on to second life and go swimming, I just built a virtual pool.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I can’t look at you or your avatar right now.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sounds like your neighbour’s home.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Don’t forget the mail you took accidentally on purpose so you’d have an excuse to talk to her.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, right, right right right right.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Stealing snail mail, very old school, I like it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (exiting to hallway)
utterance.content: Penny, the mailman did it again, he… Oh! Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Um, no, hi Leonard, this is Doug, Doug, this is my neighbour Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Doug
utterance.content: What’s up bro.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Not much. Bro.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Is, is everything okay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, yeah, uh, I just, I got your mail again, here.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thank you, I’ve got to talk to that mailman.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh no, that’s probably not such a good idea. Civil servants have a documented propensity to, you know, snap.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, well, thank you, again.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No problem. Bye. Oh, and, bye, bro! .

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny for your thoughts.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What’s the matter.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I’m fine. Penny’s fine, the guy she’s kissing is really fine and…

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Kissing, what kind of kissing? Cheeks? Lips? Chaste? French?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What is wrong with you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m a romantic.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Please don’t tell me that your hopeless infatuation is devolving into pointless jealousy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I’m not jealous, I’m just a little concerned for her. I didn’t like the look of the guy that she was with.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Because he looked better than you?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah. He was kinda dreamy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, at least now you can retrieve the black box from the twisted smouldering wreckage that was once your fantasy of dating her, and analyse the data so that you don’t crash into geek mountain again.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I disagree, love is not a sprint, it’s a marathon. A relentless pursuit that only ends when she falls into your arms. Or hits you with the pepper spray.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, I’m done with Penny. I’m going to be more realistic and go after someone my own speed.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Like who?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know. Olivia Geiger?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The dietician at the cafeteria with the limp and the lazy eye?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I don’t think you have a shot there. I have noticed that Lesley Winkle recently started shaving her legs. Now, given that winter is coming one can only assume that she is signalling sexual availability.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t know, you guys work in the same lab.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: There are pitfalls, trust me, I know. When it comes to sexual harassment law I’m… a bit of a self-taught expert.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look, Howard, if I were to ask Lesley Winkle out it would just be for dinner, I’m not going to walk into the lab, ask her to strip naked and dance for me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, then you’re probably okay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hello Lesley.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Hi Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Lesley I would like to propose an experiment.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Goggles, Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Right. Lesley, I would like to propose an experiment.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Hang on. I’m trying to see how long it takes a five hundred kilowatt oxygen iodine laser to heat up my cup o’ noodles.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Pfff, I’ve done it, about two seconds, 2.6 for minestrone. Anyway, I was thinking more of a bio-social exploration with a neuro-chemical overlay.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Wait, are you asking me out?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I was going to characterise it as the modification of our colleague/friendship paradigm, with the addition of a date-like component. But we don’t need to quibble over terminology.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: What sort of experiment would you propose?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There is a generally accepted pattern in this area, I would pick you up, take you to a restaurant, then we would see a movie, probably a romantic comedy featuring the talents of Hugh Grant or Sandra Bullock.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Interesting. And would you agree that the primary way we would evaluate either the success or failure of the date would be based on the bio-chemical reaction during the goodnight kiss.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Heartrate, pheromones, etc, yes.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Well, why don’t we just stipulate that the date goes well and move to the key variable.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You mean, kiss you now?

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Can you define the parameters of the kiss?

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Closed mouth but romantic. Mint?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you. . Shall I count down from three?

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: No, I think it needs to be spontaneous.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: What do you think.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You proposed the experiment, I think you should present your findings first.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Fair enough. On the plus side, it was a good kiss, reasonable technique, no extraneous spittle. On the other hand, no arousal.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: None?

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: None.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Ah. Well, thank you for your time.

utterance.speaker: Lesley
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: None at all?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, if you were a robot, and I knew and you didn’t, would you want me to tell you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That depends. When I learn that I’m a robot, will I be able to handle it?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Maybe, although the history of science-fiction is not on your side.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Uh, let me ask you this. When I learn that I’m a robot, would I be bound by Asimov’s three laws of robotics?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You might be bound by them right now.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s true. Have you ever harmed a human being, or through inaction allowed a human being to come to harm?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course not.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Have you ever harmed yourself, or allowed yourself to be harmed except in cases where a human being would have been endangered?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, no.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I smell robot.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (entering)
utterance.content: Hey, what’s going on.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The internet’s been down for half an hour.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Also, Sheldon may be a robot.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, how did it go with Lesley?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, we tried kissing, but the earth didn’t move. I mean any more than the 383 miles that it was going to move anyway.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I’ve seen that look before. This is just going to be two weeks of moping and tedious emo songs, and calling me to come down to pet stores to look at cats. I don’t know if I can take it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You could power down.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, as usual, Wolowitz has the solution. I happen to know a place where there are plenty of eligible women, and Leonard could have his pick.

utterance.speaker: Class instructor
utterance.content: Remember the Latin hips. Shoulders stay still, and we sway. One two three. Five six seven.

utterance.speaker: Howard (to Leonard)
utterance.content: I think Mrs Tishman’s got her eye on you. I’ve been there, you’re in for a treat.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, good lord.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (singing)
utterance.content: You don’t know me, you don’t wear my chains… God, that’s a good song.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If you’re compiling a mix CD for a double suicide. Oh, I hope that scratching post is for you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I know what you’re thinking, I’ve taken your asthma into account. There’s a feline geneticist in San Diego who has developed the cutest little hypo-allergenic calicos.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, listen to me…

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’ve been thinking about names, I’m kind of torn between Einstein, Newton and Sergeant Fuzzyboots.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, do you really think you can satisfy your need for a relationship with a genetically altered cat?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Maybe, if it’s a cute little cuddly cat.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, come on, Leonard! This is obviously about Penny.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It doesn’t matter. The woman’s not interested in me, the woman rejected me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, look, I think that you have as much of a chance of having a sexual relationship with Penny as the Hubble Telescope does of discovering at the centre of every black hole is a little man with a flashlight searching for a circuit breaker. Nevertheless, I do feel obligated to point out to you that she did no reject you. You did not ask her out.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re right. I didn’t ask her out, I should ask her out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. No, now that was not my point. My point was, don’t buy a cat.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, but you’re right. I should march over there and ask her out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, goody, we’re getting a cat.

utterance.speaker: Penny (opening door)
utterance.content: Ah, hey Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Good afternoon Penny, so hi, hey. Uh… I was wondering if you had plans for dinner.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, do you mean dinner tonight?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There is an inherent ambiguity in the word dinner. Technically it refers to the largest meal of the day whenever it is consumed, so, to clarify here, by dinner I mean supper.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Supper?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Or dinner. I was thinking six thirty, if you can go, or a different time.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Uh, six thirty’s great.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really? Great!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, I like hanging out with you guys.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Us guys?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know, Sheldon, Howard, Raj, who all’s coming?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: They…. might all be there. Or a subset of them might be there, uh, algebraically speaking there are too many unknowns, for example Sheldon had Quizznos for lunch, sometimes he finds that filling, other times he doesn’t, it’s no fault of Quizznos, they have a varied menu.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, whatever, it sounds like fun.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Great. Did we say a time?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Six thirty.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: And that’s still good for you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Cos it’s not carved in stone.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, six thirty’s great.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’ll get my chisel.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: To… carve the… okay, I’ll see you six thirty.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How do I look?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Could you be more specific?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Can you tell I’m perspiring a little?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. The dark crescent-shaped patterns under your arms conceal it nicely. What time is your date?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Six thirty.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Perfect, that gives you two hours and fifteen minutes for that dense molecular cloud of Aramis to dissipate.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Is it too much?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not if you’re a rugby team.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: By the way, if it should ever come up, you didn’t join us because you stuffed yourself with a chicken carbonara sub at Quizznos.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why would I join you?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No reason. Oh, you know what, maybe this isn’t such a good idea.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, no, no, no, well now, there’s always the possibility that alcohol and poor judgement on her part might lead to a nice romantic evening.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re right, alcohol, poor judgement, it could go well.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course, there’s the other possibility that this date kicks off a rather unpleasant six months of the two of you passing awkwardly in the hall until one of you breaks down and moves to another zip code.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You could have stopped at “it could go well.”

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If I could of, I would of.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I mean, I’m a perfectly nice guy. There’s no reason we couldn’t go to the restaurant and have a lovely dinner. Maybe take a walk afterwards, talk about things we have in common, “you love pottery? I love pottery!” You know, there’s a pause, we both know what’s happening, I lean in, we kiss, it’s a little tentative at first but then I realise, she’s kissing me back, and she’s biting my lower lip, you know, she wants me, this thing is going the distance, we’re going to have sex! Oh God! Oh, my God!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is the sex starting now?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m having a panic attack.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, okay, well then, calm down.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If I could calm down I wouldn’t be having a panic attack, that’s why they call it a panic attack.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Alright, alright, well, just, sit down, yes, sit down, now close your eyes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Just do it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now try to increase your alpha-wave activity.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s a bio-feedback technique, it’s relaxation through brain-wave manipulation, I read a paper about it in the Journal of American Neuroscience, it was a little sparsely sourced but I think the basic science is valid, I probably have it here somewhere.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, who am I kidding, I can’t go through with this, you need to call her and cancel.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Me?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What should I tell her.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know. Tell her I’m sick.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Not the kind of illness that will make her want to come over and take care of me, but nothing so critical that she’ll feel uncomfortable going out with me in the future if I want to try this again.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Got it. So I’m assuming nothing venereal. I’ll just tell her that you had a routine colonoscopy and haven’t quite bounced back.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Give me the phone.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But I thought you wanted to cancel?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I can’t because if I don’t show up she’ll still be expecting you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why would she be expecting me?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Stop asking me all these questions, I need to take another shower.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So are the rest of the guys meeting us here?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, yeah, no. Turns out that Raj and Howard had to work, and Sheldon had a colonoscopy and he hasn’t quite bounced back yet.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ooh, my uncle just had a colonoscopy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re kidding, well, then, that’s something we have in common.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: How?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We both have people in our lives who… want to nip intestinal polyps in the bud.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, what’s new in the world of physics?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Really, nothing?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, with the exception of string theory, not much has happened since the 1930’s, and you can’t prove string theory, at best you can say “hey, look, my idea has an internal logical consistency.”

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ah. Well I’m sure things will pick up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s new at the Cheesecake Factory?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, uh, not much. We do have a chocolate key lime that’s moving pretty well.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Good. Good. And what about your, uh, hallway friend.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Doug? Oh, yeah, I dunno, I mean, he’s nice and funny, but…

utterance.speaker: Waitress
utterance.content: Can I get you started with some drinks?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, You were saying, but…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’d like a drink.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just say the but thing about Doug and then I’ll get her back.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, well, you know, it’s just me. I’m still getting over this break-up with Kurt, and this thing with Doug would be just rebound sex.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Ugh, don’t get me started on rebound sex.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It’s just, it’s my pattern. I break up, then I find some cute guy, and then it’s just thirty six meaningless of… well, you know.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m not sure that I do. Um, is that one thirty-six hour experience, or is it thirty six hours spread out over say, one… glorious summer.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, it’s usually over a weekend, and trust me, you do not feel good after it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, chafing, right?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Emotionally.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Of course, yeah, emotional chafing. Hey, do you want to see something cool? I can make this olive go into this glass without touching it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: How?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Physics. .

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Wow, centrifugal force!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Actually, it’s centripetal force, which is an inward force generated by the glass acting on the olive. Excuse me. Now, if you were riding on the olive, you’d be in a non-inertial reference frame, and would

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, I’m okay. Did you spill ketchup?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m not okay.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Are you sure you don’t want to go to the emergency room?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, no, I’m okay, it’s stopped bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I know, but you did throw up. Isn’t that a sign of a concussion?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, but I get car sick too, so…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sorry about your car, by the way.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, no, it’s fine, you got most of it out the window.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: The poor guy on the bike. I had a nice time.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, me too. Um, good night. Leonard?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Was this supposed to be a date?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: This? No. No, of course not, this was just you and me hanging out with a bunch of guys who didn’t show up, because of work and a colonoscopy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I was just checking.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: When I take a girl out on a date, and I do, she knows she’s been dated. Capital D. Bold face, underline, like Day-ted. I think I might have a little concussion, I’m going to go lay down for a while, good night.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So, how was your date?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Awesome!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Score one for liquor and poor judgement.

utterance.speaker: Teleplay
utterance.content: Bill Prady _ Steven Molaro

utterance.speaker: Story
utterance.content: Chuck Lorre
